abstract.p: Rick Rubow letter praises Nov 27 article about children of divorce; says what they really need is one or two loving parents with similar values to raise them, whether in one household or two

block.p: Re ''More Options to Answer 'What About the Kids?' '' (Nov. 27):

Re ''More Options to Answer 'What About the Kids?' '' (Nov. 27):

Congratulations on a well-written piece. The key critical issue was raised up front -- that any comparisons between children of divorce and those of intact families must look at high-conflict intact families. Elizabeth Marquardt is described as a scholar associated with a pro-marriage organization. Her conclusions, however, seem to be based on an unpublished, not peer-reviewed, survey that supports her individual feelings and the bias of her organization.

As a psychologist who has done hundreds of custody mediations and studies, I do not believe we need moralistic junk science foisted on parents who already feel tremendous guilt over their decision to separate. Those who end up in court are often in high-conflict relationships, where the kids are glad to be out of a stressful and sometimes dangerous household.
We can all agree that what kids really need is one or two loving parents with similar values, who work together to raise them, whether in one household or two.
